answer: Red triangle warning sign indicating areas where wild animals frequently cross roads. Drivers must reduce speed and stay alert, especially at dawn and dusk.
Basic right-of-way rule: vehicles approaching from the right have priority at unmarked intersections unless signs indicate otherwise.
Speed limit within built-up areas is 50 km/h unless otherwise posted. Begins at yellow town sign, ends at crossed-out sign.
Octagonal red sign requiring complete vehicle stop at stop line. Must yield to all traffic before proceeding through intersection.
Yellow diamond sign indicating you're on priority road. You have right-of-way at intersections until sign is cancelled.
Default speed limit outside built-up areas is 100 km/h for cars. Different limits apply for trucks, trailers, and adverse conditions.
Red triangle with shovel and pile symbol warns of construction zone ahead. Expect lane changes, workers, machinery, and reduced speeds.
Vehicles inside roundabout have priority. Yield before entering, signal right when exiting, no stopping inside the circle.
Recommended speed is 130 km/h on unrestricted sections. No general limit exists, but posted limits and conditions must be observed.
Round sign with red border showing two cars prohibits overtaking. Applies until next intersection or cancellation sign appears.
Red triangle with curved arrow warns of sharp left curve ahead. Reduce speed before entering curve, maintain control throughout.
Blue square with white P indicates parking area. Additional signs may show restrictions, time limits, or payment requirements.
When turning right, yield to pedestrians and cyclists crossing your path. Check mirrors and blind spots before turning.
Special zone where pedestrians have priority, may use entire street. Maximum speed walking pace, parking only in marked areas.
Speed limit typically 30 km/h. Pedestrians have priority, children may play. Drive carefully and be prepared to stop.
Red triangle with cross warns of intersection ahead without priority indication. Approach carefully, prepare to yield to right.
Blue rectangular sign with white arrow indicates one-way traffic. Driving against direction is prohibited except for authorized vehicles.
Reduced speed limit near schools, typically 30 km/h during school hours. Watch for children crossing, buses stopping.
White rectangular sign below main sign showing times when regulation applies. Outside those times, normal rules apply.
When turning left, yield to oncoming traffic and crossing pedestrians. Position vehicle near center line, signal early.
Area with 30 km/h limit marked by zone sign. Right-before-left rule typically applies at all intersections within zone.
Red triangle showing slope percentage warns of steep downhill. Use lower gear, avoid excessive braking to prevent brake fade.
Inverted red triangle requires yielding to traffic on priority road. Slow down, be prepared to stop if necessary.
Shows road has no through passage. May have pedestrian or bicycle passage. Plan route accordingly, prepare to turn around.
Must reduce speed in rain, snow, fog, or ice below posted limits. Adapt to visibility and road conditions for safety.
Red triangle with opposing arrows warns oncoming traffic shares your lane ahead. Reduce speed, stay right, prepare to yield.
Round red sign with white horizontal bar prohibits entry. Usually marks one-way street exit or restricted area.
Blue sign with car symbol indicates road for motor vehicles only. Minimum speed capabilities required, pedestrians and bicycles prohibited.
Priority road bends; thick line shows priority direction. Vehicles continuing on priority must still signal and exercise caution.
Red triangle showing upward slope warns of steep uphill. Lower gear may be needed, watch for slow-moving vehicles ahead.
Cars with trailers limited to 80 km/h outside towns, 100 km/h on highways with approval. Lower limits may apply.
Shows distance to hazard or how long regulation continues. Helps drivers prepare appropriately for upcoming situation.
Red triangle warns of road narrowing ahead. Reduce speed, prepare to yield if oncoming traffic present in narrow section.
Blue sign with walking figure indicates pedestrian-only area. Vehicle entry generally prohibited except delivery vehicles at specified times.
Priority at next intersection only; doesn't extend beyond. Other signs or rules determine priority at subsequent intersections.
Red triangle with bumps warns of uneven road surface ahead. Reduce speed to avoid vehicle damage and maintain control.
Orange signs with arrows guide drivers around closed roads. Follow numbered or colored detour route to destination.
Round blue sign with white number shows minimum required speed. Applies unless conditions make it unsafe to maintain speed.
Red triangle warns of falling rocks or debris from cliffs. Drive alertly, avoid stopping in danger zone if possible.
Sign indicates end of congestion zone. May resume normal speed gradually while monitoring traffic ahead.
Streetcars always have priority unless otherwise signed. Yield when they're entering or leaving stops, crossing paths.
Red triangle warns of strong crosswinds. Grip steering firmly, reduce speed, especially with high-profile vehicles or trailers.
Red circle prohibits all vehicle traffic. May have exceptions shown on additional signs for residents or deliveries.
Square blue sign with white number recommends speed but isn't legally binding. Often used on highways as recommended maximum.
Red triangle with snowflake warns of ice or snow on road. Reduce speed significantly, increase following distance, drive gently.
Sign shows road merging from side. If on priority road, you have right-of-way. Still check for merging vehicles.
Electronic overhead signs show changing speed limits based on traffic, weather, or accidents. Limits are legally binding when displayed.
Red triangle with running children warns of school, playground, or area with children. Reduce speed, expect sudden movements.
White arrows on blue background show mandatory direction at intersection. Must follow arrow direction, cannot choose alternative.
Parking area reserved for loading/unloading goods. Time restrictions usually apply. Regular parking may be prohibited.
Red triangle warns of groove or depression across roadway. Reduce speed to prevent damage and loss of vehicle control.
Yellow diamond with gray diagonal stripes cancels priority road. Standard right-before-left or other signs now apply.
Trucks over 3.5 tons limited to 80 km/h outside towns, 60 km/h with trailer. Different limits on highways.
Red triangle with airplane warns of low-flying aircraft near airport. Expect noise, don't stop unnecessarily, stay alert.
Blue round sign with bicycle indicates mandatory bike path. Bicycles must use path; cars prohibited except for crossing.
Yield sign with roundabout arrows means traffic in circle has priority. Wait for gap, merge smoothly without stopping unnecessarily.
Red triangle warns of movable bridge ahead. Bridge may open; watch for signals, be prepared to stop.
Arrow below sign indicates which direction regulation applies. Important for one-sided parking restrictions or priority.
No specific posted limit for rain, but adapt speed to conditions. Reduce significantly if visibility impaired or aquaplaning risk.
Red triangle warns of pedestrian crossing ahead. Slow down, be prepared to stop for pedestrians waiting or crossing.
Blue circle with red border and red X prohibits stopping except for passenger embarkation/disembarkation, maximum 3 minutes.
When multiple vehicles have priority, right-before-left applies among them. Eye contact and courtesy help resolve simultaneous arrival.
Red triangle warns of migrating amphibians crossing road seasonally. Drive slowly, watch road surface to avoid killing animals.
Blue disc showing arrival time required in restricted zones. Set to arrival time rounded up to next half-hour.
Visibility under 50 meters requires maximum 50 km/h. Use fog lights, increase following distance, avoid unnecessary overtaking.
Red triangle warns of livestock being herded across or along road. Slow down, follow herder's instructions, avoid frightening animals.
Blue circle with red border and diagonal red line prohibits all stopping and parking. Applies in direction of arrow.
Buses signaling to leave stop have priority to merge into traffic. Drivers must allow buses to pull out safely.
Red triangle warns of loose gravel or stones on road. Reduce speed, maintain safe distance, risk of flying stones.
Round sign with diagonal stripes through number cancels specific speed limit. Default limits or new signs now apply.
Red arrow facing you means yield to oncoming traffic in narrow section. Blue arrow means you have priority.
Red triangle warns road near water without barrier. Drive carefully, risk of skidding into water if leaving road.
Sign indicates multi-story parking facility. Follow directional signs, observe height restrictions and internal traffic rules.
Speed limit with weather symbol applies only during specified conditions like rain or snow. Normal limits when conditions clear.
Red triangle warns of railway crossing with barriers ahead. Stop at red lights or closed gates, never drive around.
Blue circle with red border and diagonal line prohibits parking. Stopping up to 3 minutes allowed for loading/unloading.
At T-intersection, through traffic has priority over joining traffic unless signs indicate otherwise. Check for priority signs.
Red triangle with exclamation mark warns of unspecified hazard. Additional sign usually specifies danger. Proceed with caution.
Zone sign with diagonal stripes marks end of zone. Previous general rules resume unless new zone begins.
Stopping prohibited during times shown on additional sign. May allow stopping nights, weekends, or outside specified hours.
Blue lights and siren require immediate right-of-way. Pull to right, stop if necessary. Don't follow emergency vehicles.
Triangle warns of reduced clearance to side. May indicate narrow bridge, wall, or obstacle. Reduce speed, stay centered.
Some areas have nighttime speed reductions for noise protection. Posted signs show times, typically 22:00-06:00.
Plate below sign reading Anlieger frei means residents and delivery vehicles exempted from restriction.
On multi-lane roads with equal priority, right-before-left applies per lane. Each lane yields independently to its right.
Red triangle warns of bicycle traffic crossing or joining. Watch for cyclists especially at intersections and bike paths.
Parking area reserved for residents with permits. Non-residents may receive fines. Permits typically displayed in windscreen.
Posted speed limits on autobahn override no-limit sections. Strictly enforced, often for construction, curves, or congestion.
X-shaped sign marks railway crossing without barriers. Stop if train approaching, look both ways, cross quickly when clear.
Sign indicates parking for transferring to public transport. Often free or reduced-cost parking near stations.
When lanes merge, alternate one-by-one like zipper at merge point. Don't merge early; use full lane length.
Maintain half your speedometer reading in meters as minimum following distance. Three-second rule alternative: watch fixed point.
Maintain 1.5 meters minimum when overtaking cyclists, 2 meters for children. More distance required at higher speeds.
Distance traveled while braking. Formula: speed divided by 10, squared. Example: 50 km/h = 25 meters on dry road.
Distance traveled during reaction time before braking begins. Formula: speed divided by 10, times 3. Example: 50 km/h = 15 meters.
Total distance to stop: reaction distance plus braking distance. Must maintain this distance to vehicle ahead.
Accelerate on ramp to match highway speed. Yield to highway traffic, merge into gap using acceleration lane fully.
In traffic jams, create center corridor for emergency vehicles. Left lane moves left, all others move right.
Hard shoulder only for emergencies and breakdowns. Stopping prohibited except in emergency. Keep clear for rescue vehicles.
Overtaking permitted only on left side on highways. Passing on right prohibited except in slow-moving traffic queues.
Alternative distance method: vehicle should reach your position 2 seconds after vehicle ahead passes fixed point.
Braking distance doubles on wet roads. Triple distance on ice. Adjust following distance accordingly in poor conditions.
Check mirrors, signal, verify gap, accelerate smoothly past, maintain safe clearance, signal and return when clear ahead.
Maintain greater following distance in tunnels. Recommended: half speedometer value in meters, minimum 2-second rule.
Maximum braking effort requires full pedal pressure. ABS prevents wheel lock, allowing steering during braking.
No overtaking zones include intersections, pedestrian crossings, poor visibility curves, railway crossings, and narrow passages.
Signal early, move to right lane well before exit. Use deceleration lane to slow down, not highway lane.
Sign prohibits trucks over 3.5 tons from overtaking. Applies on two-lane highways, often on hills or congested sections.
In stopped traffic, maintain 2-3 meter gap to vehicle ahead. Allows maneuvering and escape route if needed.
Need clear view of entire overtaking distance before starting maneuver. Generally requires 500-800 meter visibility depending on speed.
Following too closely is illegal and dangerous. Can result in fines, points, or license suspension if causing accidents.
130 km/h recommended speed on unrestricted autobahn. Not legally binding but affects liability in accidents exceeding it.
May only stop on shoulder for emergencies. Turn on hazard lights, use warning triangle, exit vehicle safely behind barrier.
When doubling speed, quadruple the braking distance. Example: 100 km/h needs four times the distance of 50 km/h.
No legal minimum speed on autobahn, but vehicles must be capable of 60 km/h. Driving unnecessarily slowly can be penalized.
Trucks overtaking slightly slower trucks for extended periods. Causes congestion, may be prohibited in certain sections.
Check mirrors and blind spot, signal intention, make smooth gradual movement. Verify sufficient space before changing lanes.
Merge lane for entering highway. Use entire length to match traffic speed. Yield to highway traffic already present.
Exit lane for leaving highway. Move to exit lane first, then reduce speed using full deceleration lane length.
Signal 3 seconds before changing lanes. Check three mirrors and shoulder check. Change lanes smoothly and decisively.
Additional uphill lane for slow-moving vehicles on steep grades. Faster traffic uses left lanes to maintain flow.
In flowing traffic, aim for 2-3 second gap. Adjust based on weather, visibility, and road conditions.
Passing motorhomes and campervans requires more time and distance. Ensure clear visibility and adequate space before overtaking.
Activate hazard lights briefly when approaching sudden traffic jam rear. Alerts following drivers to brake early.
Drive in rightmost lane unless overtaking on multi-lane highways. Left lanes are for passing only, not cruising.
Police and emergency vehicles need more following distance due to sudden stops. Give them extra clearance and right-of-way.
On ice, braking distance multiplies by 10 compared to dry conditions. Extremely gentle braking and slow speeds essential.
Overtaking multiple vehicles requires proportionally longer clear distance. Often safer to overtake one vehicle at a time.
Stay in right lane when not overtaking. Move right after passing. Multiple lane changes discouraged without reason.
Begin slowing only after fully entering exit lane. Reducing speed on highway lane creates dangerous situation for following traffic.
Trucks need 50 meters minimum following distance at highway speeds. Longer stopping distances require greater gaps.
Left lane on multi-lane highways reserved for active overtaking. Must return to right lane after completing pass.
Keep shoulders and between-lane space clear in jams. Emergency vehicles need unobstructed path through traffic.
Never change lanes directly in front of faster approaching vehicle. Always check mirror and ensure adequate clearance distance.
Heavy traffic requires increased following distance despite slower speeds. Frequent braking and unpredictable driver behavior present hazards.
Complete overtaking maneuvers quickly to minimize time in oncoming lane. Extended passing increases risk and traffic disruption.
Hard shoulder reserved for breakdowns only. Walking on shoulder prohibited except to reach emergency phone or exit safely.
Greater speed difference requires longer overtaking distance. Passing 20 km/h faster needs much more space than 10 km/h.
Minimum legal tire tread depth is 1.6 mm. Recommended 3 mm for summer, 4 mm for winter tires for safe braking.
Insufficient following distance can result in fines and points. Severe tailgating may lead to license suspension or jail.
Overtaking on parallel lanes permitted in congested multi-lane traffic moving under 60 km/h. Right may pass left slowly.
When traffic slows suddenly, check rearview mirror and activate hazard lights to warn following vehicles before hard braking.
Short entrance ramp requires earlier speed matching and decisive merging. Watch for gaps, don't stop unless absolutely necessary.
Emergency braking distance shorter than normal due to maximum brake application. ABS allows steering while braking maximally.
Match general traffic speed on highways within legal limits. Driving significantly slower than flow can create hazards.
Reversing on autobahn strictly prohibited and extremely dangerous. Missed exit requires continuing to next exit to turn around.
Total distance needed includes: approach, alongside, and return clearance. Must be visible and clear throughout entire maneuver.
Unnecessarily occupying left lane while right lane clear violates keep-right rule. Can result in fines up to €80.
Reduced speed limits strictly enforced in work zones. Lanes narrower, barriers present. Follow posted speeds and lane markings.
Broken-down vehicles on shoulder must display warning triangle 150 meters behind on highway. Use hazard lights, wear safety vest.
In fog, increase following distance significantly. Use fog lights, reduce speed, avoid overtaking in limited visibility conditions.
Worn highway lanes with grooves can affect steering. Maintain firm grip, avoid sudden movements, reduce speed in heavy rain.
U-turns on autobahn absolutely prohibited. Use designated exits and interchanges to reverse direction safely and legally.
Continuously adjust following distance for changing speeds, weather, visibility, and traffic density throughout journey.
Driving wrong way on autobahn extremely dangerous and illegal. If occurs accidentally, stop safely, use emergency phone immediately.
Zipper merge system where vehicles from merging lanes alternate one-by-one when a lane ends, typically at construction zones.
Must maintain 1.5m to cyclists, 2m to pedestrians when overtaking. Inside towns, 1m minimum to parked vehicles.
Total stopping distance equals reaction distance plus braking distance. Depends on speed, road conditions, and driver alertness.
Only permitted on one-way streets or where tram tracks prevent right-side parking. Otherwise, always park right.
Accelerate on entry ramp to match traffic speed. Autobahn traffic has right of way; merging driver must yield.
Prohibited on highways except when left lane traffic is stationary or moving under 60 km/h in traffic jams.
Braking distance in meters equals speed divided by 10, then squared. Example: 50 km/h = (50÷10)² = 25 meters.
Absolute stopping ban indicated by sign with red X. No stopping or parking permitted in this zone.
Emergency corridor formed between leftmost lane and others on highways during traffic jams for emergency vehicles.
Overtaking strictly forbidden when continuous double white lines mark road center. Severe penalties apply for violations.
Maintain half your speedometer reading in meters. Example: at 100 km/h, keep 50 meters distance minimum.
Must park at least 5 meters from intersection edge or pedestrian crossing. 8 meters if vision-obstructing objects present.
Acceleration lane for entering highways. Use full length to reach traffic speed before merging into flow.
Forbidden to overtake before and on hilltops where oncoming traffic cannot be seen for sufficient distance.
Reaction distance equals speed divided by 10, multiplied by 3. Example: 50 km/h = (50÷10)×3 = 15 meters.
Limited stopping ban shown by single red diagonal line. Parking forbidden but brief stops for loading permitted.
Hard shoulder reserved for emergencies only. Using for driving except when signed permitted results in heavy fines.
Complete overtaking maneuver within reasonable time. Lengthy parallel driving beside other vehicles is prohibited.
Emergency braking halves normal braking distance. At 50 km/h, reduces from 25m to approximately 12.5 meters.
Never block garage or driveway exits. Violators may be towed at their expense immediately.
Motor vehicle road minimum speed requirement. Vehicles must be capable of exceeding 60 km/h to use.
Overtaking prohibited at pedestrian crossings and immediately before them. Stop if pedestrians are waiting or crossing.
Alternative distance rule: maintain at least 2 seconds travel time behind vehicle ahead under normal conditions.
Generally prohibited unless specifically permitted by sign showing vehicle partially on curb. Heavy fines otherwise.
No general minimum speed, but vehicles must be capable of 60 km/h. Unnecessarily slow driving can be fined.
Forbidden before and within tight curves where visibility of oncoming traffic is insufficient for safe overtaking.
Braking distance doubles on wet roads. At 50 km/h, increases from 25m to 50 meters for normal braking.
No stopping within 15 meters before bus stop sign. Buses must have clear access to stop zone.
Deceleration lane for exiting highways. Move into lane before braking; don't slow down in through lanes.
May cross solid line only to overtake cyclists, mopeds, or slow vehicles if safe and visibility clear.
In winter conditions or bad weather, increase safety distance to at least 3-4 seconds following time.
Designated parking areas at highway exits for carpooling. Special rules and time limits may apply.
Keep right except when overtaking. Middle and left lanes for passing only, return right after completing.
Permitted if safe and sufficient visibility exists for entire maneuver. Ensure adequate distance throughout.
On ice, braking distance can increase five to ten times normal distance. Drive extremely cautiously.
On narrow streets, parking prohibited if less than 3 meters remain for traffic flow in each direction.
Only use hard shoulder for genuine breakdowns or emergencies. Activate hazard lights immediately when stopping.
May briefly flash headlights outside towns to signal overtaking intention, but not to pressure others.
Highway guideposts spaced 50 meters apart help judge following distance. Use for quick safety distance checks.
Blue parking disc must show arrival time clearly in designated zones. Maximum stay typically 1-2 hours.
Reduced speed limits strictly enforced. Lane markings may change; yellow temporary markings override white permanent ones.
When school bus shows hazard lights and stops, no overtaking allowed. Pass at walking pace maximum 7 km/h.
Insufficient distance is serious offense. Results in fines, points, and potential driving ban depending on severity.
Blue zones marked for loading only. Maximum 3 minutes stop for quick delivery or pickup operations.
Digital displays adjust limits based on traffic, weather, or accidents. Limits legally binding when illuminated.
Must not exceed posted speed limit when overtaking. Speed limit applies to all vehicles regardless of maneuvers.
With anti-lock brakes, apply full steady pressure. Don't pump brakes; ABS automatically prevents wheel locking.
Absolute parking ban in fire department access zones marked by special signs. Immediate towing authorized.
Exit signs on autobahn numbered and show distance. Exits typically 500m warning, then 300m, then exit.
Strictly forbidden to overtake within railway crossing zones or immediately before them. Severe penalties apply.
Trucks over 3.5 tons must maintain 50 meters minimum distance from other trucks on highways.
Special permits allow residents to park in designated zones where general parking prohibited or time-limited.
Drive on right rule. On multi-lane highways, use rightmost lane unless overtaking. Center lanes for passing.
Overtake stopped trams only on right at walking speed. If passengers crossing, stop completely.
For vehicles without ABS, pump brakes rapidly to prevent wheel lock on slippery surfaces. Maintains steering control.
Reserved for vehicles displaying valid disabled permit. Unauthorized use results in fine plus towing.
Construction zone limits strictly monitored by cameras. Often 80 km/h or 60 km/h with reduced tolerance.
When one vehicle overtakes, do not immediately follow without checking safety independently. Maintain proper spacing.
Use engine braking on long descents. Select lower gear to prevent brake overheating and maintain control.
Yellow curb indicates no parking or stopping zone. Yellow markings override conflicting white markings.
Right lane for normal driving, middle for overtaking slower traffic, left for overtaking middle lane. Return right.
Give motorcycles full lane width when overtaking. Don't force them toward road edge; maintain 1.5m clearance.
Braking distance shorter uphill, longer downhill. Account for gradient when judging safe following and stopping distances.
Must park in direction of traffic flow. Parking facing wrong direction prohibited except on one-way streets.
Speed limit valid only when electronic signs active. When blank, standard limits apply for road type.
On highways with congestion, may carefully pass right when left lanes slower. Not permitted in free-flowing traffic.
Continuous braking causes overheating and reduced effectiveness. Use engine braking to prevent brake fade.
Park as close to curb as safely possible. Maximum 50cm from curb edge permitted.
Designated parking areas with facilities. Maximum stay typically 3 hours unless emergency. No overnight parking allowed.
Only overtake when clear visibility for entire maneuver. If uncertain about oncoming traffic distance, do not overtake.
Modern vehicles activate hazard lights automatically during hard braking. Warns following traffic of sudden deceleration.
Special regulations in garages: typically 10 km/h limit, keep ticket visible, follow directional arrows strictly.
Wrong-way driver alerts on radio. If you're going wrong way, stop safely immediately, don't reverse.
Tractors and slow farm vehicles may be overtaken with care. Watch for turning movements and wide loads.
Apply maximum brake pressure just before wheel lock point. Most effective technique for shortest stopping distance.
Blue zones require parking disc showing arrival time. Free parking but limited duration, typically 1-2 hours.
Unnecessarily staying in middle lanes when right lane free is prohibited. Can be fined for improper lane use.
Generally prohibited in shorter tunnels. Longer tunnels may permit overtaking where marked; follow tunnel-specific signs.
Heavy loads increase braking distance significantly. Factor extra weight into following distance and braking points.
Parking parallel to already-parked vehicle strictly forbidden. Blocks traffic flow and subject to immediate towing.
Highway interchange where autobahn connects to other roads. Numbered and signed with destination information.
Must return to right lane after overtaking as soon as safely possible. Don't linger in passing lanes.
Worn tires increase braking distance up to 50%. Legal minimum tread depth 1.6mm; recommended 3mm minimum.
Display valid parking ticket clearly on dashboard. Digital payment apps increasingly accepted; note zone number.
Distribution circle where multiple autobahn routes meet. Follow signs carefully for correct exit direction.
When overtaken by emergency vehicle with sirens, move aside immediately. Stop if necessary to clear path.
ABS prevents wheel lock but doesn't reduce braking distance. Still requires appropriate following distance.
Areas marked with tow-away symbol enforce strict parking bans. Vehicle removed at owner's expense immediately.
Full-service stops with fuel, food, restrooms. Parking permitted for reasonable duration during facility use.
Always check mirrors and blind spot before overtaking. Modern systems assist but don't replace visual checks.
On 10% downgrade, braking distance increases approximately 2x. Use lower gears for prolonged descents.
Generally allowed on streets unless posted otherwise. Check local regulations; many residential areas restrict trucks.
Highway intersection where two autobahns cross. Multiple exits require attention to overhead signs and lane guidance.
Check mirrors, signal intent, check blind spot, execute overtaking. Follow proper sequence for safety.
Doubling speed quadruples braking distance and impact energy. Small speed increases significantly affect safety margins.
Diagonal parking requires backing in or pulling through for easy exit. Follow marked direction arrows.
Form emergency corridor, hazard lights on, keep clear path between lanes. Stay in vehicle unless immediate danger.
Racing or aggressive overtaking competitions strictly illegal. Results in heavy fines, points, and license suspension.
Total stopping distance varies with speed, conditions, reaction time. Always maintain distance allowing safe stop.
Environmental zones require emission sticker. Low-emission vehicles only; parking without proper sticker fined.
If unable to merge safely, use hard shoulder at lane end rather than forcing way into traffic.
Trucks create wind turbulence. Maintain firm steering grip and extra clearance when passing large vehicles.
Red brake warning requires immediate stop. Amber ABS light means proceed cautiously to service location.
Smaller marked spaces designated for compact vehicles only. Full-size vehicles parking there may be ticketed.
Move to right lane well before exit. Use deceleration lane for slowing; don't brake in through lane.
Too-close overtaking of cyclists or pedestrians is traffic offense. Minimum distances legally enforced.
Water depth and speed create hydroplaning risk. Reduce speed significantly in heavy rain to maintain tire contact.
Need 1.5 times vehicle length to parallel park safely. Front and rear space should allow comfortable maneuvering.
Merge at lane end using zipper system, not early. Both lanes use full length for efficient traffic flow.
Dangerous overtaking maneuvers can result in criminal charges beyond traffic fines. Severe penalties for endangerment.
Soft or spongy brake pedal indicates problem. Requires immediate professional inspection; may be dangerous to drive.
Many churches prohibit parking during services except for attendees. Respect posted restrictions and special event notices.
Exit to hard shoulder, park far right, activate hazards, place warning triangle, exit vehicle safely.
Passing on right is overtaking violation except in traffic jams. Left lane for overtaking on free-flowing roads.
Fatigue, alcohol, drugs, distractions increase reaction time. Standard calculation assumes 1 second alert driver reaction.
Motorcycles may park in specially marked areas. In some cities, free parking in marked car spaces permitted.
Recommended 130 km/h on unrestricted autobahn sections. Not legally binding but affects liability in accidents.
After overtaking, check right mirror before returning to right lane. Ensure sufficient gap for safe lane change.
Excessive braking overheats discs, reducing effectiveness. Allow cooling periods; use engine braking when possible.
Temporary no-parking during scheduled cleaning. Posted signs show day, time. Vehicle removed if obstructing cleaning.
Stay in through lanes until reaching your exit approach. Don't cross multiple lanes at last moment.
Prohibited within and immediately before intersections. Vehicles ahead may turn without extensive checking.
Distributes brake force between front and rear wheels. Front brakes do most work; rear prevents spinning.
Property owner may prohibit parking. Private towing companies enforce restrictions; vehicle removed at owner expense.
Speed limits adjust automatically based on traffic flow, weather, accidents. Electronic signs display current limits.
Motorcycles and bicycles vulnerable to side wind from large vehicles passing. Give extra clearance.
Modern vehicles achieve roughly 1g deceleration maximum. Depends on tire grip, surface conditions, ABS function.
Residents-only or permit-only areas restrict non-resident parking. Obtain proper authorization or use public parking nearby.
Many autobahn sections have no lighting. Use proper headlights; reduced visibility increases risk of all maneuvers.
Signal right when returning to lane after passing. Indicates intention; helps following drivers anticipate movements.
Apply brakes smoothly and progressively rather than suddenly. Prevents skidding and maintains vehicle stability.
Reserved for actively charging EVs. Non-electric vehicles or non-charging EVs parking may be fined.
Yellow signs override white permanent signs. Valid until explicitly cancelled by end-of-restriction sign.
When overtaking multiple vehicles, others should wait until first completes. Prevents dangerous crowding in passing lane.
Fully loaded vehicle requires significantly longer stopping distance. Increase following distance proportionally to load weight.
